News and developments from Justia and the tech world -----
December 2016
 

Welcome to the December 2016 edition of 
the Justia monthly client newsletter!

Get an inside look at new developments in technology and online marketing, keep up with the latest social media trends, and hear about what’s happening at the Justia offices as we wrap up a great year and celebrate the season!

Featured News

Teaching the Robots to Read: Structured Data for the Semantic Web

Since the advent of search engines, machines have evolved from simply indexing the content on your website to actually reading and understanding your content in order to provide more precise answers to user queries. On our Onward blog, one of Justia’s own engineers explains the role of structured data in this process, and how it is critical for your webmaster to understand how it impacts your site’s SEO.

Tip of the Month

Double Check Your "Google My Business" Updates

Be careful when changing your address, phone number, domain name, or firm name in your “Google My Business” listing. Before saving your changes, always double-check your edits to ensure that your key information is the same throughout all your properties. If you need help or advice about changing information in your Google My Business listing, let our team know and we’ll be happy to help!

Tech News

Trump and Net Neutrality: How Republicans Can Make the Rules Go Away

Net neutrality advocates are concerned that the incoming presidential administration and/or Congress will undermine gains made in this area under the Obama administration. Current FCC rules provide that internet service providers may not block lawful Internet traffic or speed up services in exchange for payment, but these rules may be in jeopardy under the new leadership. However, insiders say that change is not a given, and that Republicans may be too divided on the issue of net neutrality to agree on any sweeping revisions to current law.

Google and Facebook Take Aim at Fake News Sites

Following criticism that fake news stories disseminated via Google and Facebook influenced the outcome of the recent presidential election, the two tech giants have announced that they are banning fake news sites from using their advertising services. While it is not clear how much of an effect these policies will have on the overall circulation of fake news, this attack on fake news sites’ sources of revenue is a first step toward curbing the reach of these stories. It also represents an acknowledgement by Google and Facebook of the power their services have to sway the American electorate, a notion that Facebook has dismissed repeatedly in the past.

Firefox's New iPhone Browser Hides You from Advertisers' Eyes

In a move underscoring the tension between advertisers and web users, Firefox has released a new browser for iPhone and iPad that blocks ads from tracking your online activity. In addition to addressing privacy concerns, the new browser offers a performance boost due to the slow-down ads cause on many mobile websites. It also speeds up web browsing by eliminating menus and tabs.

Mobile Internet Usage Surpasses Desktop for First Time Ever Worldwide

Last month mobile internet usage surpassed desktop usage worldwide for the first time ever. While users in the US and UK continue to rely more heavily on desktop devices than users in some other countries, this trend highlights the growing importance of mobile friendly website content and design for businesses across all industries.

Snapchat Files for $25 Billion IPO

In what is expected to be the largest tech debut in several years, Snapchat’s parent company has confidentially filed paperwork with the SEC for an initial public offering. While the company is seeking valuation of between $20 and $25 billion, reports indicate that it could reach as much as $40 billion. Industry insiders hope that Snapchat’s offering could generate more activity in what has been a sluggish tech IPO market in recent years.

SEO News

How to Avoid an Outbound Link Penalty from Google

This article explains how, similar to inbound links from other sites to yours, outbound links from your site to others can be detrimental if Google determines that the links are “unnatural” or “irrelevant.” In order to avoid penalties, it is critical to avoid linking to low-quality or spammy content, and to monitor outbound links on your site.

Google Revamps Article Structured Data Documentation for AMP

Google has revised their guidelines related to article markup for AMP pages, such that web developers must now use structured data on those pages in order for them to be eligible for display among rich results rather than simply as blue links along with other Google search results. This article also describes other new requirements that differentiate how AMP versus non-AMP pages are displayed in search results.

Bing Update: Search and Save for Later

Bing has announced a new feature that will allow users to save the results of searches for videos, images, shopping, and locations. Available for both desktop and mobile, this feature allows users who save a search while logged in to review the results later from any device. The service does not currently include the option to save search engine query results.

How to Boost Exposure for Local Website Pages

This article provides a succinct review of the key components of a successful local SEO campaign. Incorporating critical elements into your website such as unique content, appropriate keyword usage, NAP consistency, and internal linking can help boost SERP rankings and organic traffic, and put your business on the map.

Social Media News

70% of Consumers Will Leave a Review for a Business When Asked

BrightLocal reported in its 2016 Local Consumer Review Survey that consumers are increasingly using the Internet to find local businesses and select which business to patronize based on online reviews. Accordingly, businesses must optimize their online presence in their local markets by soliciting online reviews. The survey also revealed that approximately 70% of respondents said they will leave a review for a business if they’ve been asked to do so, making this a useful strategy to raise a business’s online profile.

How to Use Twitter Moments for Business

Last month, Twitter opened its Moments to all users, allowing them to tell stories through a series of linked tweets, videos, and images. Users can also track events like news stories, concerts, and sports in real-time. In this article, users will learn strategies to create stories and use Twitter Moments specifically for their business.

LinkedIn Rolls Out Audience Insights

LinkedIn is in the process of launching audience insights for its mobile app. This feature will allow users to view real-time insights into who is reading posts they’ve shared, what companies these visitors work for, and their location and job title, as well as how they discovered the shared content.

Awesome Hacks to Promote Your Social Media Posts

Social media can be a great way to expose potential clients to your brand, but frequent changes to each platform necessitate staying ahead of the curve with your outreach efforts. This article offers tips to help ensure that you’re making the most of your business’s social media accounts.

Twitter's Biggest Anti-Troll Effort to Date is Finally Here

Twitter is seeking to curtail hateful messages and other problematic content on its service through policy changes and an expanded “mute” feature. This update aims to combat abuse on Twitter by allowing users to filter out notifications that contain user-designated words, phrases, usernames or hashtags.

Facebook Threatens LinkedIn With Job Opening Features

Facebook may be looking to compete with LinkedIn with the advent of options to list available job opportunities on Facebook Business Pages. Business owners may now see a ‘Jobs’ tab on their Facebook Page, and Facebook has also recently confirmed that it is evaluating the effectiveness of several different recruiting features that may ultimately rival those on LinkedIn.

Facebook to Ban ‘Ethnic Affinity’ Targeting for Housing, Employment, Credit-Related Ads After Criticism from Lawmakers

Facebook recently announced that it will no longer allow advertisers to target employment, housing, and credit-related ads posted on the social network by “ethnic affinity.” The ban comes after widespread pushback from lawmakers, the media, and civil rights leaders in the US over the potential discriminatory effects posed by such restrictions.

LinkedIn is Now Officially Blocked in Russia

LinkedIn has run afoul of a Russian law that requires all websites to store Russian users’ personal data on servers located in the country. As a result, Roskomnadzor, Russia’s communications regulator, has begun enforcing a country-wide block of LinkedIn. While Google and Apple have reportedly complied, both Twitter and Facebook still appear to be storing their data associated with Russian users outside of Russia.

Legal Industry News

California Bar: Client Information Available from Public Sources is Still Confidential

The State Bar of California Standing Committee on Professional Responsibility and Conduct reaffirmed a view on lawyers’ duty of confidentiality toward their clients in a recent advisory opinion. Specifically, the Committee reaffirmed past authority, which stated that attorneys may not disclose information that was learned via their representation of a client--particularly information that is embarrassing in nature. This extends to information that can technically be obtained elsewhere due to its public availability, if that information was disclosed to a client’s attorney in confidence.

How Trump’s Victory and GOP Senate Control Could Shape the Law

Donald Trump’s election victory signals the potential for stark changes in US law in the coming months and years. A Trump presidency, along with a Republican-controlled Senate, almost certainly guarantees that President Obama’s choice of Judge Merrick Garland for the Supreme Court will not progress beyond his nomination. Beyond this open Supreme Court seat, the court’s oldest justices lean liberal, meaning that Trump’s power to shape the court may extend well beyond a single replacement for Antonin Scalia during his presidency.

Court Dockets Will Shrink as Donald Trump Rescinds Obama Administration Actions

Cases that are on the docket at the Supreme Court could shrink as a result of policy shifts after Donald Trump takes office in January. The same goes for dockets at lower federal courts. These include cases involving immigration matters, the Affordable Care Act, climate change, and LGBT rights, many of which arose from Obama administration executive actions and legal interpretations.

Reporters Could Bolster First Amendment with Libel Cases Against Trump, Libel Defense Lawyer Says

A First Amendment attorney has urged other press lawyers to be on the offensive about free speech rights after the election. This line of action involves shoring up the First Amendment by potentially bringing libel cases against Donald Trump in the event that he untruthfully claims that reporters are publishing false material.
